timeline.author: rsynek

timeline.bodyText:
I wonder if this code can throw ConcurrentModificationException:
In the loop, another thread calls registerExtractors. As a result, some extractors may be removed.
Safe approach could be e.g. making getLabelValueExtractors return a defensive copy of the original Set.
timeline.author: rsynek

replies.bodyText:
Let's say that this could happen in very a "theoretically" worst case, but in practice will never happen. Since the extractors are "configurable" but will never change at run-time or processing time. Instead they are laded at the extension startup as part of all the "planning related" stuff and will never change again.
I didn't add any additional sync mechanism for performance purposes given the statement above.
replies.author: wmedvede

replies.bodyText: If they are not supposed to be changed after startup, we can make the registerExtractors method private to enforce that and even remove the synchronized keyword from there.
replies.author: rsynek

replies.bodyText:
what I'm saying is that registrations can be made as part of the extension initialization. During this time the LabelValueExtractors will never be consumed. Finally only after the extension was initialized, and all potential registration was already produced, the extractors might start being used.
I think current format is ok.
replies.author: wmedvede

timeline.bodyText: Collections.emptyMap() will do the same thing, and will save a lot of memory in the process.
timeline.author: triceo

timeline.bodyText: Dtto. There's more occurences in this file, incl.Collections.emptySet().
timeline.author: triceo

timeline.bodyText: Personally, I would keep only setLabelValues(labelName, values). If you have to keep this method as well, consider at least defensively copying the Map.
timeline.author: triceo

replies.bodyText: the setLabelValues(Map<String, Set> labelValues) was mainly defined in case this is something that Solution cloners, or any other internal OptaPlanner mechanims use. ¿?

timeline.bodyText: Consider renaming to countMatchingLabels, which makes it obvious at first glance, what this method does.

timeline.bodyText:
In my opinion, this would read better:
`.stream().filter(taskLabelValues::contains).count()`

timeline.bodyText:
Isn't this a normal property file? If so, you can read it using Properties class from the JDK.
When you have the Properties, you can further parse them yourself - but the Properties class will do the underlying I/O and syntax checking for you.
